Plotly Works Look

For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.

import numpy as np
import plotly.express as px

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * 180 * r

# Set rticks
px.line_polar(r=r, theta=theta, start_angle=0, direction="counterclockwise")

Quick Maths

More

\(\sum_i^n r_i=\sum_i^n s(q_i-z)\)

\(=\frac{s[(\sum_i^nq_i)-nz]}{n}\)

\(=\frac{s}{n}\sum q_i-sz\)

Accounting for the output scale…

\(r_y=\sum_i^n r_{xi}=\sum_i^n s_x(q_{xi}-z_x)\)

\(r_y=\frac{s_x[(\sum_i^nq_{xi})-nz_x]}{n}\)

\(r_y=\frac{s_x}{n}\sum q_{xi}-sz_x\)

\(s_y(q_y-z_y)=\frac{s_x}{n}\sum q_{xi}-sz_x\)

\(q_y=\frac{s_x}{s_yn}\sum q_{xi}-\frac{s_x}{s_y}z_x+z_y\)

Some Verilog

When writing verilog

module boxmaker #(
  parameter bigNess = $clog2(64),
  parameter highNess = 12,
) (
  input clk, nrst,
  logic [bigNess-1:0][highNess-1:0] box_o,
);

  always@(posedge clk or negedge nrst) begin
    if (!nrst)
      box_o <= '0;
    else
      for (int row = 0; row=row+1;row < highNess) begin
        box_o <= row;
      end

  end


endmodule

Got this
